recipe.title: Spring Shepherd's Pie  with Cremini Mushrooms & English Peas
recipe.description: By the 18th Century, the potato (native to the Americas) had won favor in Europe, and began appearing in a range of European comfort dishes. One delicious example is shepherd’s pie, a British classic which combines a hearty meat and vegetable filling with a creamy mashed potato crust. Our spring shepherd’s pie features ground lamb and beef cooked with fresh English peas, cremini mushrooms and traditional spices—all baked under a layer of mashed Yukon Golds. It’s a warming, wholesome way to welcome some of spring’s first produce.

stories.title: Yukon Gold Potatoes
stories.description: These thin-skinned, golden-fleshed potatoes are a relative newcomer to the agricultural market (they were developed by Canadian researchers in the 1960s), but their popularity is no surprise. They are often referred to as an “all-purpose” potato, as they are excellent in any number of preparations, including boiling, baking, roasting and frying. When cooked, they become especially creamy in texture, with a delicious, buttery flavor.

stories.title: Cremini Mushrooms
stories.description: These brown, firm mushrooms are a popular variety for cooking. Like white mushrooms, which they're related to, cremini mushrooms have smooth caps, and are known for their stronger flavor. When allowed to mature further, they develop into large-capped portobello mushrooms.

stories.title: Yellow Onion
stories.description: This unassuming Allium likely originated in Central Asia or the Middle East and has been cultivated for at least 5,000 years. The Egyptians thought the onion symbolized eternal life—frequently, Egyptian priests are depicted holding onions in art from the time. For many ancient civilizations, like those of China, India, Greece and Rome, onions were considered to have medicinal properties. To help improve their performance before Olympic competition, Ancient Greek athletes consumed onions by the pound. Today, we use yellow onions—considered the universal, all-purpose onion—for their robust layers and spicy, sharp and sweet flavor profile.

stories.title: English Peas
stories.description: Technically a kind of legume (like beans or lentils), peas are native to Western Asia. They’ve been cultivated since the Bronze Age. They spread to India and China by the 7th Century. (In Chinese, the word for pea translates to “foreign legume.”) During that time, peas (also called “field peas”) were quickly becoming a staple of European Medieval cuisine. These cuisines featured almost exclusively the pea itself (the seed of the plant). They’re still delicious and another sign that spring has sprung!

stories.title: Butter
stories.description: What would cooking be without butter? Butter is so essential to so many cuisines and dishes across the world that its absence seems almost unimaginable. Millennia ago, butter was made from goat or sheep's milk (before the domestication of cattle). In Northern Europe, cooler climates made it easier to store butter for longer periods of time. But even in the warm climates of the eastern Mediterranean, the Middle East and India, butter was used and treasured for its rich, exquisite taste (often in the form of ghee, or other clarified butter preparations). From sautéing and frying to baking and sauce-making, butter has been used in countless ways.

stories.title: Tomato Paste
stories.description: This concentrated ingredient is full of rich flavor. It's made by stewing fresh tomatoes down, reducing their water content and intensifying the tomatoes. Originally, making tomato paste was a way to preserve tomatoes long beyond their season, but it can do so much more! We like to use it whenever we want to add depth of flavor quickly. In many of our recipes, we'll provide instructions for how to caramelize the paste. It has a higher concentration of natural fruit sugars, which transform when heated. Try it and taste the difference!

stories.title: Vegetarian Worcestershire Sauce
stories.description: Found in everything from Caesar salads to cocktails (think Bloody Mary), Worcestershire is an incredibly popular sauce. It was first made by John Wheeley Lea and William Henry Perrins, pharmacists in the town of Worcester. The sauce they concocted is a potent mixture of various ingredients, including malt vinegar, molasses, garlic, spices and tamarind paste. Its somewhat pickled flavor highlights savory preparations, brightening their flavors and providing a delicious contrast. Though early recipes for the sauce contained fish, there are now entirely vegetarian versions that maintain the sauce's complex taste.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

ingredients.description: Shepherd's Pie Spice Blend (All-Purpose Flour, Mustard Powder, Garlic Powder, Ground Fennel Seeds, Ground Bay Leaf & Ground Dried Thyme)
ingredients.customer_facing_name: 1/4 Cup Shepherd's Pie Spice Blend (All-Purpose Flour, Mustard Powder, Garlic Powder, Ground Fennel Seeds, Ground Bay Leaf & Ground Dried Thyme)
ingredients.customer_facing_ingredient_name: Cup Shepherd's Pie Spice Blend (All-Purpose Flour, Mustard Powder, Garlic Powder, Ground Fennel Seeds, Ground Bay Leaf & Ground Dried Thyme)

stories.title: Shepherd's Pie Spice Blend
stories.description:
We’re adding flour to our Shepherd’s pie in order to thicken the hearty meat and veggie filling. For added depth of flavor, we’re combining the flour with some potent spices: mustard powder, aromatic fennel seeds, bay leaf, garlic powder and dried thyme.

5 Parts All-Purpose Flour

1 Part Mustard Powder

1 Part Ground Fennel Seeds

1 Part Ground Bay Leaf

1 Part Garlic Powder

1 Part Ground Dried Thyme

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the onion to the pan of mushrooms; season with salt and pepper. (If the pan seems dry, add 1 teaspoon of olive oil.) Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until softened. Add the ground lamb and beef; season with salt and pepper. Cook, frequently breaking the meat apart with a spoon, 5 to 7 minutes, or until browned and cooked through. Carefully drain off and discard any drippings from the pan.

Add the potatoes to the pot of boiling water. Cook 14 to 16 minutes, or until tender when pierced with a fork. Drain thoroughly and return to the pot. Off the heat, add the butter; stir to combine. Using a fork, mash the mixture to your desired consistency; season with salt and pepper to taste. Set aside in a warm place.
While the potatoes cook, in a large, high-sided pan (or pot), heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the mushrooms. Cook, stirring occasionally, 5 to 7 minutes, or until browned.

Preheat the oven to 475°F. Wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a medium pot of salted water to boiling on high. Peel and large dice the potatoes. Cut the mushrooms into small pieces. Peel and small dice the onion. Shell the peas.

stories.title: How To: Small Dice an Onion
stories.description: Small dice an onion? No sweat (but maybe a few tears). Check out this video to see exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Dice a Potato
stories.description: Cut large for roasting, or small for soups and stews, there’s a special trick to quickly dicing a potato. Check out the video to see how our chefs do it.

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!

recipe_steps.step_text: Transfer the finished filling to a baking dish. Using a spatula or fork, evenly spread the mashed potatoes over the filling. Sprinkle with the cheese; season with salt and pepper. Bake 12 to 14 minutes, or until lightly browned around the edges. Remove from the oven and let stand for at least 2 minutes before serving. Enjoy!

Add the tomato paste to the pan of vegetables and meat. Cook, stirring frequently, 1 to 2 minutes, or until the tomato paste is dark red. Add the peas and spice blend; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 1 to 2 minutes, or until fragrant and the peas are bright green. Add the Worcestershire sauce and 1 cup of water; season with salt and pepper. Cook, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan, 2 to 3 minutes, or until the liquid has thickened. Remove from heat; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: Shepherd's Pie Spice Blend
stories.description:
We’re adding flour to our Shepherd’s pie in order to thicken the hearty meat and veggie filling. For added depth of flavor, we’re combining the flour with some potent spices: mustard powder, aromatic fennel seeds, bay leaf, garlic powder and dried thyme.

5 Parts All-Purpose Flour

1 Part Ground Bay Leaf

1 Part Garlic Powder

1 Part Ground Dried Thyme

They are often referred to as an “all-purpose” potato, as they are excellent in any number of preparations, including boiling, baking, roasting and frying. When cooked, they become especially creamy in texture, with a delicious, buttery flavor.

recipe.title: Za'atar-Spiced Chicken with Tabbouleh, Roasted Cauliflower & Tzatziki
recipe.description: In this dish, you’ll serve pan-seared chicken—coated in the robust Middle Eastern spice blend za’atar—with homemade tzatziki, a cooling sauce of seasoned Greek yogurt. Our tzatziki combines yogurt with lemon juice, grated cucumber and garlic paste. It’s perfect with the zesty chicken, or dolloped on top of za’atar-roasted cauliflower. To round out the meal, we’re also making the Middle Eastern grain salad tabbouleh with bulgur (or cracked wheat), spinach and fresh lemon juice.

stories.title: Spinach
stories.description: A member of the beet family, spinach likely originated in Persia, where it was cultivated as early as the 4th Century. Over the next several centuries, it made its way to Europe and Eastern Asia. It grows fast, and has a prized, tender texture, stunning green color and subtly sweet flavor. In fact, in the Middle Ages, spinach was often used as an ingredient in sweet dishes and desserts.

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: White Cauliflower
stories.description: A cauliflower is actually a member of the cabbage family whose flowers don’t grow past the bud stage, resulting in the plant’s familiar dense florets. To preserve the striking white color of the cauliflower, farmers will often pull its large leaves over its head and tie them together, covering the cauliflower like a hat—and keeping the head from being exposed to direct sunlight.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Za'atar
stories.description: Za’atar refers to a family of herbs, including thyme, oregano and marjoram. But it’s also the Middle Eastern condiment made from those herbs in combination with sesame seeds, sumac and other spices. Traditionally sun-dried, za’atar is often eaten with pita or used as seasoning for various meats, vegetables and hummus. Recipes for za’atar were once considered so precious that they were kept secret—even from family members.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the bulgur cooks, wash and dry the fresh produce. Grate the cucumber. Peel and mince the garlic; using the flat side of your knife, smash until it resembles a paste (or use a zester). Quarter and deseed the lemon. Cut out and discard the cauliflower core; cut the head into bite-sized florets. In a bowl, combine the yogurt, grated cucumber, garlic paste and the juice of 2 lemon wedges; season with salt and pepper to taste.
recipe_steps.step_title: Prepare the ingredients & make the tzatziki:

stories.title: How To: Make Garlic Paste
stories.description: In some of our recipes, the directions say to smash the garlic cloves into a paste as opposed to mincing them. But why smash? It has to do with how garlic cloves grows. Inside each clove are tiny pockets of essential oil, the most flavorful part. If you're using the garlic raw, it’s important to smash these pockets, releasing as much of the oil as possible and giving it a chance to infuse the whole dish with flavor. Our executive chef Matt Wadiak has created a short video to show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Peel Garlic
stories.description: If you're cooking with us, you're using garlic in virtually every recipe. Don't waste any more time trying to peel it! Check out the video for a quick tip.

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

stories.title: How To: Prep Cauliflower Florets
stories.description: Cauliflower is one of our favorite cool-weather vegetables. In certain recipes, we specify to cut the head into small florets. Check out this short video to learn the simple technique that will make prepping cauliflower a snap!

recipe_steps.step_text: While the cauliflower roasts, pat the chicken dry with paper towels; season on both sides with salt, pepper and the remaining za’atar. In a large pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned chicken, skin sides down. Cook 4 to 6 minutes per side, or until browned and cooked through. Transfer to a serving dish and set aside in a warm place, leaving any browned bits (or fond) in the pan.

stories.title: How To: Pan-Fry Chicken
stories.description: This essential technique yields perfectly-cooked chicken with a delicious, crispy skin. The process is incredibly easy. Check out this short video to see how it's done!

recipe_steps.step_text: While the cauliflower continues to roast, add 1 teaspoon of olive oil to the pan of reserved fond and heat on medium-high until hot. Add the spinach and cook, stirring occasionally, 1 to 2 minutes, or until wilted. Transfer to the pot of cooked bulgur. Add the juice of the remaining lemon wedges and a drizzle of olive oil. Stir to combine and season with salt and pepper to taste. Transfer to a serving dish. Serve the tabbouleh, cooked chicken and roasted cauliflower with the tzatziki on the side. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Make the tabbouleh & serve your dish:

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: Preheat the oven to 450°F. Heat a large pot of salted water to boiling on high. Once boiling, add the bulgur and cook 12 to 14 minutes, or until tender. Turn off the heat. Drain thoroughly and return to the pot.

stories.title: How to Cook Your Grains "Pasta" Style
stories.description: In some of our recipes, we have you measure out water to cook your grains in. In others, we only specify to heat a pot of boiling water and add the grains to it. For the grain in this recipe, an exact ratio of water to grain isn't necessary. You just need enough boiling water to give the grain some room and let it dance: a few quarts will do. We chose this method because it's more streamlined and easier for hearty grains (like farro, spelt and wild rice). Just think: cook it like pasta!

recipe_steps.step_text: Place the cauliflower on a sheet pan; drizzle with olive oil and season with salt, pepper and half the za’atar. Toss to thoroughly coat. Arrange in a single, even layer and roast, stirring halfway through, 18 to 20 minutes, or until lightly browned and tender when pierced with a fork. Remove from the oven. Transfer to a serving dish and set aside in a warm place.

stories.title: Za'atar
stories.description: Za’atar refers to a family of herbs, including thyme, oregano and marjoram. But it’s also the Middle Eastern condiment made from those herbs in combination with sesame seeds, sumac and other spices. Traditionally sun-dried, za’atar is often eaten with pita or used as seasoning for various meats, vegetables and hummus. Recipes for za’atar were once considered so precious that they were kept secret—even from family members.

stories.title: Bulgur
stories.description: Bulgur is a versatile, filling grain made from Durum wheat. The word itself is Turkish and the grain is a staple of the region’s cuisine. Bulgur’s heartiness and natural nutty flavor make it as delectable as it is healthful.

stories.title: White Cauliflower
stories.description: A cauliflower is actually a member of the cabbage family whose flowers don’t grow past the bud stage, resulting in the plant’s familiar dense florets. To preserve the striking white color of the cauliflower, farmers will often pull its large leaves over its head and tie them together, covering the cauliflower like a hat—and keeping the head from being exposed to direct sunlight.

stories.title: Persian Cucumber
stories.description: Small, crisp, sweet and seedless, Persian cucumbers are a particularly tasty variety. With origins likely in the Fertile Crescent (where North Africa meets the Middle East), they're among the most historic of cucumbers. Their thin skin is delicious and edible, too.

stories.title: How To: Pan-Fry Chicken
stories.description: This essential technique yields perfectly-cooked chicken with a delicious, crispy skin. The process is incredibly easy. Check out this short video to see how it's done!

stories.title: How To: Make Garlic Paste
stories.description: In some of our recipes, the directions say to smash the garlic cloves into a paste as opposed to mincing them. But why smash? It has to do with how garlic cloves grows. Inside each clove are tiny pockets of essential oil, the most flavorful part. If you're using the garlic raw, it’s important to smash these pockets, releasing as much of the oil as possible and giving it a chance to infuse the whole dish with flavor. Our executive chef Matt Wadiak has created a short video to show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: Greek Yogurt
stories.description: Greek yogurt is yogurt that has been strained to remove the liquid whey, leaving a thicker, creamier texture as well as a higher protein content than regular yogurt. It’s been enjoyed in Eastern Europe, North Africa and Asia for centuries. Thanks to its thickness, it’s excellent in cooking, especially as the base of cooling yogurt sauces, as a marinade or as a substitute for buttermilk or heavy cream.

stories.title: Spinach
stories.description: A member of the beet family, spinach likely originated in Persia, where it was cultivated as early as the 4th Century. Over the next several centuries, it made its way to Europe and Eastern Asia. It grows fast, and has a prized, tender texture, stunning green color and subtly sweet flavor. In fact, in the Middle Ages, spinach was often used as an ingredient in sweet dishes and desserts.

stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe.title: Hoisin-Mayo Salmon Burgers with Roasted Sweet Potato Rounds
recipe.description: In this recipe, we’re making salmon burgers flavored with garlic, ginger and hoisin sauce, a sweet and savory Chinese barbecue-style sauce. (We’re also using hoisin in a delicious mayonnaise that we’re slathering on our toasted potato buns.) Chefs, in order to ensure your burgers are the perfect consistency, be sure to let the mixture rest at least 5 minutes once you’ve combined the ingredients in step 4. This gives the breadcrumbs time to moisten, making the burgers easy to form.

stories.title: Potato Buns
stories.description: Potato bread, a type of bread in which potato replaces a portion of the regular wheat flour, was historically associated with times of economy—when wheat became expensive during grain shortages, potato was a cheap and easy substitute. However, delicious potato bread quickly earned a permanent place on the bakery shelf. The secret is the starches in the potatoes. These dilute the gluten-forming protein of the wheat, making the resulting bread extraordinarily tender and moist—and giving it the pillowy, soft chew it’s known for. Formed into buns for sandwiches or burgers, it provides exquisite textural contrast to patties and fillings.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Sweet Potato
stories.description: Despite its name, the sweet potato is not related to the group vegetables we know as “potatoes”—rather, the sweet potato is actually a member of the morning glory family. Columbus brought the tropical root crop, native to the Americas, back to Europe after his 1492 trip to the New World. It was eagerly adopted by Europeans and given the title of “potato” (from its indigenous Taino name, “batata”). Years later, in 1537, when the white potato first arrived in Europe, locals began referring to both vegetables as “potatoes,” creating a confusion that persists today. It wasn’t until the 1740s that American colonists developed the term “sweet potato” to distinguish the delicious tuber from its white counterpart.

stories.title: Cilantro
stories.description: Cilantro is one of the most refreshing herbs. It's unbelievably tasty and a perfect, herbaceous complement to all kinds of other flavors. Cilantro and the spice coriander actually come from the same plant. Coriander is the seeds, whereas cilantro is the long, leafy shoots that grow from them.

stories.title: Hoisin Sauce
stories.description: This thick, pungent sauce is a tremendously popular barbecue-like sauce used in Chinese cooking. It’s a favorite for grilling and marinades, as a dipping sauce, or an addition to stir-fries. It’s made from soybeans, garlic, and other aromatics and flavorings, and has a delicious sweet and spicy flavor.

stories.title: Ginger
stories.description: This delicious, knobby root is native to southern China, and from there it spread to the Spice Islands (in present-day Indonesia), West Africa and the Caribbean. Ginger began appearing in Europe in the 1st Century. Botanically, it's most closely related to turmeric, cardamom and galangal, but it has a distinct flavor. Ginger has very many uses, both candied and pickled. It also has natural preservative qualities. And while we love it in all forms, we like it best minced and added to dishes where its lightly spicy, fresh flavor can truly shine.

stories.title: Sesame Seeds
stories.description: The tiny seeds of the sesame plant (native to the African savannah), sesame seeds are known for their pleasantly nutty flavor, which deepens when the seeds are roasted or toasted. They come in a variety of colors, including white, golden, brown and black, and are a beloved garnish for a number of dishes, adding tasty crunch and flavor. In fact, they have been sprinkled on breads for millennia (with written reference as early as the 1st Century AD).

stories.title: Panko Breadcrumbs
stories.description: What makes panko so special? As strange as it may seem, panko isn’t baked… it’s electrocuted. The dough is allowed to rise naturally, then it’s placed between metal plates. High voltages are passed through the bread, cooking it. The electrocuted bread has distinct advantages. Essentially, it has no crust and is dried throughout. This means that even after they've been cooked (again, in this recipe), the breadcrumbs will be crunchy, light and airy.

stories.title: Mayonnaise
stories.description: This thick, creamy sauce is the result of a unique process known as emulsion—or a blend of two liquids wherein one forms tiny droplets that are suspended in the other. In the case of traditional mayonnaise, oil droplets are evenly dispersed in a mixture of egg yolk, water and lemon juice or vinegar. By slowly whisking the oil into the base of egg yolk, water and acid, it breaks into small droplets, thickening the mixture and creating mayonnaise’s signature consistency. Although frequently used as a condiment, mayonnaise also makes an excellent ingredient in dressings, and it’s a favorite to lock in moisture when breading meat or poultry.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the sweet potatoes continue to roast, in the pan used to cook the salmon, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the burgers and cook 2 to 4 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate. Carefully wipe out the pan.

While the salmon cooks, wash and dry the fresh produce. Slice the sweet potatoes into ½-inch-thick rounds. Peel and mince the garlic and ginger. Halve the buns. Pick the cilantro leaves off the stems; discard the stems. In a bowl, combine the mayonnaise and half the hoisin sauce; season with salt and pepper to taste.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Peel & Mince Ginger
stories.description: Ginger is a common, aromatic ingredient popular in cuisines throughout the world. Because of its knobby shape, prepping ginger can seem tricky. But simply follow the instructions in this video and you'll be prepping like a pro.

recipe_steps.step_text: While the sweet potatoes continue to roast, in the same pan, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium until hot. Working in batches, add the buns, cut sides down, and toast 2 to 3 minutes, or until golden brown. Transfer to a clean, dry work surface. Spread a layer of the hoisin mayonnaise onto the cut sides of the toasted buns. Top the bun bottoms with the cooked burgers, as much of the cilantro as you’d like and the bun tops. Divide between 4 plates. Serve with the roasted sweet potatoes; garnish with the sesame seeds. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Toast the buns & serve your dish:

recipe_steps.step_text: While the sweet potatoes roast, carefully drain off and discard any liquid from the bowl of flaked salmon. Crack the eggs into a bowl; beat until smooth. To the bowl of flaked salmon, add the beaten eggs, breadcrumbs, garlic, ginger and remaining hoisin sauce. Season with salt and pepper; gently mix to combine. Set aside for 5 minutes. Using your hands, form the mixture into four ¾-inch-thick burgers, squeezing firmly to ensure the burgers are tightly packed.

Preheat the oven to 475°F. Pat the salmon fillets dry with paper towels; season with salt and pepper on both sides. In a large pan (nonstick, if you have one), heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the seasoned fillets, skinless sides down. Cook 2 to 3 minutes per side, or until browned and cooked through. Remove from heat and transfer to a large bowl. Using a fork, flake the cooked salmon into small pieces, removing and discarding the skin. Wipe out the pan.

Place the sweet potatoes on a sheet pan. Drizzle with olive oil and season with salt and pepper; toss to thoroughly coat. Arrange in a single, even layer and roast 24 to 26 minutes, or until browned and tender when pierced with a fork. Remove from the oven.

stories.title: Hoisin Sauce
stories.description: This thick, pungent sauce is a tremendously popular barbecue-like sauce used in Chinese cooking. It’s a favorite for grilling and marinades, as a dipping sauce, or an addition to stir-fries. It’s made from soybeans, garlic, and other aromatics and flavorings, and has a delicious sweet and spicy flavor.

stories.title: Potato Buns
stories.description: Potato bread, a type of bread in which potato replaces a portion of the regular wheat flour, was historically associated with times of economy—when wheat became expensive during grain shortages, potato was a cheap and easy substitute. However, delicious potato bread quickly earned a permanent place on the bakery shelf. The secret is the starches in the potatoes. These dilute the gluten-forming protein of the wheat, making the resulting bread extraordinarily tender and moist—and giving it the pillowy, soft chew it’s known for. Formed into buns for sandwiches or burgers, it provides exquisite textural contrast to patties and fillings.

stories.title: How To: Peel & Mince Ginger
stories.description: Ginger is a common, aromatic ingredient popular in cuisines throughout the world. Because of its knobby shape, prepping ginger can seem tricky. But simply follow the instructions in this video and you'll be prepping like a pro.

stories.title: Sweet Potato
stories.description: Despite its name, the sweet potato is not related to the group vegetables we know as “potatoes”—rather, the sweet potato is actually a member of the morning glory family. Columbus brought the tropical root crop, native to the Americas, back to Europe after his 1492 trip to the New World. It was eagerly adopted by Europeans and given the title of “potato” (from its indigenous Taino name, “batata”). Years later, in 1537, when the white potato first arrived in Europe, locals began referring to both vegetables as “potatoes,” creating a confusion that persists today. It wasn’t until the 1740s that American colonists developed the term “sweet potato” to distinguish the delicious tuber from its white counterpart.

stories.title: Cilantro
stories.description: Cilantro is one of the most refreshing herbs. It's unbelievably tasty and a perfect, herbaceous complement to all kinds of other flavors. Cilantro and the spice coriander actually come from the same plant. Coriander is the seeds, whereas cilantro is the long, leafy shoots that grow from them.

stories.title: Ginger
stories.description: This delicious, knobby root is native to southern China, and from there it spread to the Spice Islands (in present-day Indonesia), West Africa and the Caribbean. Ginger began appearing in Europe in the 1st Century. Botanically, it's most closely related to turmeric, cardamom and galangal, but it has a distinct flavor. Ginger has very many uses, both candied and pickled. It also has natural preservative qualities. And while we love it in all forms, we like it best minced and added to dishes where its lightly spicy, fresh flavor can truly shine.

stories.title: Sesame Seeds
stories.description: The tiny seeds of the sesame plant (native to the African savannah), sesame seeds are known for their pleasantly nutty flavor, which deepens when the seeds are roasted or toasted. They come in a variety of colors, including white, golden, brown and black, and are a beloved garnish for a number of dishes, adding tasty crunch and flavor. In fact, they have been sprinkled on breads for millennia (with written reference as early as the 1st Century AD).

stories.title: Panko Breadcrumbs
stories.description: What makes panko so special? As strange as it may seem, panko isn’t baked… it’s electrocuted. The dough is allowed to rise naturally, then it’s placed between metal plates. High voltages are passed through the bread, cooking it. The electrocuted bread has distinct advantages. Essentially, it has no crust and is dried throughout. This means that even after they've been cooked (again, in this recipe), the breadcrumbs will be crunchy, light and airy.

stories.title: Mayonnaise
stories.description: This thick, creamy sauce is the result of a unique process known as emulsion—or a blend of two liquids wherein one forms tiny droplets that are suspended in the other. In the case of traditional mayonnaise, oil droplets are evenly dispersed in a mixture of egg yolk, water and lemon juice or vinegar. By slowly whisking the oil into the base of egg yolk, water and acid, it breaks into small droplets, thickening the mixture and creating mayonnaise’s signature consistency. Although frequently used as a condiment, mayonnaise also makes an excellent ingredient in dressings, and it’s a favorite to lock in moisture when breading meat or poultry.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe.title: Creamy Pasta Primavera with SautÃ©ed Asparagus & Crispy Maitake Mushrooms
recipe.sub_title: with SautÃ©ed Asparagus & Crispy Maitake Mushrooms
recipe.description: Chefs, spring is here! And we’re celebrating with some of the first delicious produce of the season. Pasta primavera is a classic dish meant to showcase spring’s best vegetables—the word “primavera” is Italian for “spring”. Our primavera features sautéed asparagus, crispy maitake mushrooms, spinach and plenty of garlic. We’re tossing it all with linguine in a creamy sauce made with Greek yogurt and a little butter. A dusting of Parmesan completes this fresh, hearty meal.

stories.title: Linguine Pasta
stories.description: This long, flat pasta is best used in saucy dishes. In Italian, linguine means "little tongues." The pasta originated in the nothern coastal region of Italy, near Genoa. It's classically used to make linguine alle vongole (linguine with clams), but it's incredibly versatile. With simple tomato sauces, meat sauces or pesto, linguine is the perfect vehicle for flavor.

stories.title: Greek Yogurt
stories.description: Greek yogurt is yogurt that has been strained to remove the liquid whey, leaving a thicker, creamier texture as well as a higher protein content than regular yogurt. It’s been enjoyed in Eastern Europe, North Africa and Asia for centuries. Thanks to its thickness, it’s excellent in cooking, especially as the base of cooling yogurt sauces, as a marinade or as a substitute for buttermilk or heavy cream.

stories.title: Garlic
stories.description: This aromatic allium—from the same family as onions, leeks and chives—is indispensable in the kitchens of nearly every cuisine worldwide. Its delicious, pungent and spicy flavor comes from a set of specific compounds (also known for their impressive health benefits), which are activated when the cloves are smashed or cut. So chefs, mince away—your taste buds will thank you!

stories.title: Asparagus
stories.description:
Asparagus is actually the young shoot of a small shrub, harvested before its flesh becomes woody. The spade-shaped “leaves” that line its long, narrow body are, in fact, early branches, preparing to reach out of a soon-to-be tree trunk. Once classified as part of the lily family, like garlic and onions, asparagus and its wild cousins now belong to their own separate family, which contains over 100 unique genera (some of which are evergreen).

In Turkish, the name for asparagus is “kuÅŸkonmaz,” which literally translates to “bird can’t land.” That’s a decent description of the vegetable’s shape, but what it leaves out is asparagus’ exquisite tenderness.

stories.title: Lemon
stories.description:
Lemon, though we may take it for granted, is one of the most important ingredients in any kitchen. Its light, pure acidity provides a vivid contrast that brightens the other flavors of countless dishes.

The most common lemons, which we use in virtually all of our dishes, are Eureka lemons. They've been grown in the United States (specifically California) since the 1850s, from Sicilian seeds. This variety of lemon flowers and ripens in every season, though the majority of the harvest happens in late winter.

stories.title: Spinach
stories.description: A member of the beet family, spinach likely originated in Persia, where it was cultivated as early as the 4th Century. Over the next several centuries, it made its way to Europe and Eastern Asia. It grows fast, and has a prized, tender texture, stunning green color and subtly sweet flavor. In fact, in the Middle Ages, spinach was often used as an ingredient in sweet dishes and desserts.

stories.title: Maitake Mushrooms
stories.description: Also known as "hen of the woods," this gorgeous delicacy can be easily identified, as its overlapping caps are arranged like the feathers of a bird. The name maitake is Japanese and translates to “dancing mushroom” because, wild, it is said to resemble the waving hands and rippling kimono sleeves of dancing girls. Whatever they remind you of, these mushrooms are delicious!

stories.title: Butter
stories.description: What would cooking be without butter? Butter is so essential to so many cuisines and dishes across the world that its absence seems almost unimaginable. Millennia ago, butter was made from goat or sheep's milk (before the domestication of cattle). In Northern Europe, cooler climates made it easier to store butter for longer periods of time. But even in the warm climates of the eastern Mediterranean, the Middle East and India, butter was used and treasured for its rich, exquisite taste (often in the form of ghee, or other clarified butter preparations). From sautéing and frying to baking and sauce-making, butter has been used in countless ways.

stories.title: Parmesan Cheese
stories.description: Parmesan, or Parmigiano-Reggiano, is a hard cheese from Italy. It's named for the regions that produce it: Parma, Reggia Emilia, Bologna, Modena and Mantova. The name "Parmesan," and any translated form, is a protected designation of origin, meaning that only cheeses produced specifically in this region can be called "Parmesan." We can see why they would want to protect their name. This aged cheese has a distinct, granular texture and a unique, slightly nutty brininess that have made it one of the most popular European cheeses in the world. It's great for adding texture and flavor to pastas, but just as good shaved on top of salads (or eaten alone as a snack).

recipe_steps.step_text: In the pot used to cook the spinach, heat 1 tablespoon of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the mushrooms and cook, stirring occasionally, 8 to 10 minutes, or until browned and crispy. Transfer to a paper towel-lined plate, leaving any oil in the pan. Season with salt and pepper and set aside in a warm place.

While the mushrooms cook, add the pasta to the pot of boiling water. Cook 8 to 10 minutes, or until al dente (still slightly firm to the bite). Reserving ¾ cup of the pasta cooking water, thoroughly drain the cooked pasta and set aside in a warm place.

stories.title: How to Make Sure Your Pasta is Al Dente
stories.description:
Nothing beats perfectly cooked, al dente pasta. But how do you know if it's done? There are numerous ways to test the doneness of your noodles when they’re cooking. Some folk wisdom says to throw a piece of pasta against the wall; if it sticks, it's done. As much fun as we had experimenting with this method, we found the best way to test the pasta was, shockingly, by tasting it. In Italian, "al dente" means "to the tooth," meaning that it's still slightly firm to the bite. As your pasta cooks, periodically (and carefully) taste a piece of it. If it's still too firm, let it cook a little longer.

In some of our recipes, we specify to remove the pasta from the pot when it's "just shy of al dente." This is because, later, the pasta will be cooked in a sauce. Removing the pasta from the water just before it's al dente will ensure that the final product isn't overcooked.

recipe_steps.step_text: To the pot of asparagus, add the cooked pasta, chopped spinach, butter, yogurt, ¾ of the cooked mushrooms and half the reserved pasta cooking water; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until well combined. (If the sauce seems dry, gradually add the remaining pasta cooking water to achieve your desired consistency.) Season with salt and pepper to taste. Divide the finished pasta between 4 dishes. Top with the remaining cooked mushrooms. Garnish with the cheese. Serve with the lemon wedges on the side. Enjoy!
recipe_steps.step_title: Finish the pasta & serve your dish:

stories.title: How To: Season to Taste
stories.description: It’s time to talk about two of the most important ingredients in any dish: salt and pepper. Almost all of our recipes include the direction to “season with salt and pepper” more than once. Why so often? It’s a technique chefs use to build flavor. Salt is nature’s own amazing flavor enhancer. Because the taste of your dish changes and develops as you cook, intermittent seasoning allows you to bring out the character of each ingredient and highlight the complex flavors you’re creating. When seasoning, start with just a pinch and taste your dish each time you season it. That way you can be sure each layer of flavor tastes its absolute best. We've created a short video that will explain the process and show you exactly how it's done.

recipe_steps.step_text: Add the asparagus to the pot used to cook the mushrooms; season with salt and pepper. (If the pot seems dry, add 1 teaspoon of olive oil.) Cook, stirring occasionally, 1 to 2 minutes, or until slightly softened and bright green. Add the garlic. Cook, stirring frequently, 30 seconds to 1 minute, or until fragrant.

Wash and dry the fresh produce. Heat a medium pot of salted water to boiling on high. Cut the mushrooms into bite-sized pieces. Snap off and discard the tough, woody ends of the asparagus; cut the asparagus into 1-inch pieces on an angle. Peel and mince the garlic. Quarter and deseed the lemon.

stories.title: How To: Mince Garlic
stories.description: What would cooking be without garlic? Minced garlic helps create an amazing flavor base for virtually any meal. In this short video, chef Matt Wadiak will show you how to mince garlic in no time.

stories.title: How To: Quarter and Deseed a Lemon
stories.description: Lemons are indispensable to cooking. Their tart juice brightens other flavors and can tie a dish together. We’ve come up with an easy way to get the juice out of the lemon (without having to deal with the pesky seeds). Watch this short video to see how it’s done.

stories.title: How To: Properly Salt Cooking Water
stories.description: Seasoning cooking water (whether you're cooking pasta, vegetables or anything else) is imperative to building flavor. Check out this video to see how we do it!

recipe_steps.step_text: In a large pot, heat 2 teaspoons of olive oil on medium-high until hot. Add the spinach; season with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, 2 to 3 minutes, or until wilted. Transfer to a strainer; hold or rest the strainer over a bowl. Using a spoon, press down on the cooked spinach to release as much liquid as possible; discard the liquid. Transfer the drained spinach to a cutting board and finely chop. Wipe out the pot.

It's classically used to make linguine alle vongole (linguine with clams), but it's incredibly versatile. With simple tomato sauces, meat sauces or pesto, linguine is the perfect vehicle for flavor.

In Turkish, the name for asparagus is “kuÅŸkonmaz,” which literally translates to “bird can’t land.” That’s a decent description of the vegetable’s shape, but what it leaves out is asparagus’ exquisite tenderness.

Whatever they remind you of, these mushrooms are delicious!
